persona.name: Lords
persona.alias: Knights, Gentlemen, Sailors, Pirates, Fishermen, and Messengers.

scene.title: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIOCHUS, Prince PERICLES, and followers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Young prince of Tyre, you have at large received The danger of the task you undertake.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIOCHUS, Prince PERICLES, and followers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: I have, Antiochus, and, with a soul Embolden'd with the glory of her praise, Think death no hazard in this enterprise.

speech.stagedir: Enter ANTIOCHUS, Prince PERICLES, and followers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Bring in our daughter, clothed like a bride, For the embracements even of Jove himself; At whose conception, till Lucina reign'd, Nature this dowry gave, to glad her presence, The senate-house of planets all did sit, To knit in her their best perfections.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: See where she comes, apparell'd like the spring, Graces her subjects, and her thoughts the king Of every virtue gives renown to men! Her face the book of praises, where is read Nothing but curious pleasures, as from thence Sorrow were ever razed and testy wrath Could never be her mild companion. You gods that made me man, and sway in love, That have inflamed desire in my breast To taste the fruit of yon celestial tree, Or die in the adventure, be my helps, As I am son and servant to your will, To compass such a boundless happiness!

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Prince Pericles,--

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: That would be son to great Antiochus.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Before thee stands this fair Hesperides, With golden fruit, but dangerous to be touch'd; For death-like dragons here affright thee hard: Her face, like heaven, enticeth thee to view Her countless glory, which desert must gain; And which, without desert, because thine eye Presumes to reach, all thy whole heap must die. Yon sometimes famous princes, like thyself, Drawn by report, adventurous by desire, Tell thee, with speechless tongues and semblance pale, That without covering, save yon field of stars, Here they stand martyrs, slain in Cupid's wars; And with dead cheeks advise thee to desist For going on death's net, whom none resist.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Antiochus, I thank thee, who hath taught My frail mortality to know itself, And by those fearful objects to prepare This body, like to them, to what I must; For death remember'd should be like a mirror, Who tells us life's but breath, to trust it error. I'll make my will then, and, as sick men do Who know the world, see heaven, but, feeling woe, Gripe not at earthly joys as erst they did; So I bequeath a happy peace to you And all good men, as every prince should do; My riches to the earth from whence they came; But my unspotted fire of love to you. Thus ready for the way of life or death, I wait the sharpest blow, Antiochus.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Scorning advice, read the conclusion then: Which read and not expounded, 'tis decreed, As these before thee thou thyself shalt bleed.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Of all say'd yet, mayst thou prove prosperous! Of all say'd yet, I wish thee happiness!

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Like a bold champion, I assume the lists, Nor ask advice of any other thought But faithfulness and courage. I am no viper, yet I feed On mother's flesh which did me breed. I sought a husband, in which labour I found that kindness in a father: He's father, son, and husband mild; I mother, wife, and yet his child. How they may be, and yet in two, As you will live, resolve it you. Sharp physic is the last: but, O you powers That give heaven countless eyes to view men's acts, Why cloud they not their sights perpetually, If this be true, which makes me pale to read it? Fair glass of light, I loved you, and could still, Were not this glorious casket stored with ill: But I must tell you, now my thoughts revolt For he's no man on whom perfections wait That, knowing sin within, will touch the gate. You are a fair viol, and your sense the strings; Who, finger'd to make man his lawful music, Would draw heaven down, and all the gods, to hearken: But being play'd upon before your time, Hell only danceth at so harsh a chime. Good sooth, I care not for you.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Prince Pericles, touch not, upon thy life. For that's an article within our law, As dangerous as the rest. Your time's expired: Either expound now, or receive your sentence.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Great king, Few love to hear the sins they love to act; 'Twould braid yourself too near for me to tell it. Who has a book of all that monarchs do, He's more secure to keep it shut than shown: For vice repeated is like the wandering wind. Blows dust in other's eyes, to spread itself; And yet the end of all is bought thus dear, The breath is gone, and the sore eyes see clear: To stop the air would hurt them. The blind mole casts Copp'd hills towards heaven, to tell the earth is throng'd By man's oppression; and the poor worm doth die for't. Kings are earth's gods; in vice their law's their will; And if Jove stray, who dares say Jove doth ill? It is enough you know; and it is fit, What being more known grows worse, to smother it. All love the womb that their first being bred, Then give my tongue like leave to love my head.

speech.stagedir: Music. Enter the Daughter of ANTIOCHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Heaven, that I had thy head! he has found the meaning: But I will gloze with him.--Young prince of Tyre, Though by the tenor of our strict edict, Your exposition misinterpreting, We might proceed to cancel of your days; Yet hope, succeeding from so fair a tree As your fair self, doth tune us otherwise: Forty days longer we do respite you; If by which time our secret be undone, This mercy shows we'll joy in such a son: And until then your entertain shall be As doth befit our honour and your worth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: How courtesy would seem to cover sin, When what is done is like an hypocrite, The which is good in nothing but in sight! If it be true that I interpret false, Then were it certain you were not so bad As with foul incest to abuse your soul; Where now you're both a father and a son, By your untimely claspings with your child, Which pleasure fits an husband, not a father; And she an eater of her mother's flesh, By the defiling of her parent's bed; And both like serpents are, who though they feed On sweetest flowers, yet they poison breed. Antioch, farewell! for wisdom sees, those men Blush not in actions blacker than the night, Will shun no course to keep them from the light. One sin, I know, another doth provoke; Murder's as near to lust as flame to smoke: Poison and treason are the hands of sin, Ay, and the targets, to put off the shame: Then, lest my lie be cropp'd to keep you clear, By flight I'll shun the danger which I fear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: He hath found the meaning, for which we mean To have his head. He must not live to trumpet forth my infamy, Nor tell the world Antiochus doth sin In such a loathed manner; And therefore instantly this prince must die: For by his fall my honour must keep high. Who attends us there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Doth your highness call?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Thaliard, You are of our chamber, and our mind partakes Her private actions to your secrecy; And for your faithfulness we will advance you. Thaliard, behold, here's poison, and here's gold; We hate the prince of Tyre, and thou must kill him: It fits thee not to ask the reason why, Because we bid it. Say, is it done?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: My lord, 'Tis done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Enough. Let your breath cool yourself, telling your haste.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: My lord, prince Pericles is fled.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: As thou Wilt live, fly after: and like an arrow shot From a well-experienced archer hits the mark His eye doth level at, so thou ne'er return Unless thou say 'Prince Pericles is dead.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: My lord, If I can get him within my pistol's length, I'll make him sure enough: so, farewell to your highness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Antioch. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Thaliard, adieu! Till Pericles be dead, My heart can lend no succor to my head.

scene.title: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Let none disturb us.--Why should this change of thoughts, The sad companion, dull-eyed melancholy, Be my so used a guest as not an hour, In the day's glorious walk, or peaceful night, The tomb where grief should sleep, can breed me quiet? Here pleasures court mine eyes, and mine eyes shun them, And danger, which I fear'd, is at Antioch, Whose aim seems far too short to hit me here: Yet neither pleasure's art can joy my spirits, Nor yet the other's distance comfort me. Then it is thus: the passions of the mind, That have their first conception by mis-dread, Have after-nourishment and life by care; And what was first but fear what might be done, Grows elder now and cares it be not done. And so with me: the great Antiochus, 'Gainst whom I am too little to contend, Since he's so great can make his will his act, Will think me speaking, though I swear to silence; Nor boots it me to say I honour him. If he suspect I may dishonour him: And what may make him blush in being known, He'll stop the course by which it might be known; With hostile forces he'll o'erspread the land, And with the ostent of war will look so huge, Amazement shall drive courage from the state; Our men be vanquish'd ere they do resist, And subjects punish'd that ne'er thought offence: Which care of them, not pity of myself, Who am no more but as the tops of trees, Which fence the roots they grow by and defend them, Makes both my body pine and soul to languish, And punish that before that he would punish.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Joy and all comfort in your sacred breast!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: And keep your mind, till you return to us, Peaceful and comfortable!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Peace, peace, and give experience tongue. They do abuse the king that flatter him: For flattery is the bellows blows up sin; The thing which is flatter'd, but a spark, To which that blast gives heat and stronger glowing; Whereas reproof, obedient and in order, Fits kings, as they are men, for they may err. When Signior Sooth here does proclaim a peace, He flatters you, makes war upon your life. Prince, pardon me, or strike me, if you please; I cannot be much lower than my knees.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: All leave us else; but let your cares o'erlook What shipping and what lading's in our haven, And then return to us. Helicanus, thou Hast moved us: what seest thou in our looks?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: An angry brow, dread lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: If there be such a dart in princes' frowns, How durst thy tongue move anger to our face?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: How dare the plants look up to heaven, from whence They have their nourishment?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Thou know'st I have power To take thy life from thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: I have ground the axe myself; Do you but strike the blow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Rise, prithee, rise. Sit down: thou art no flatterer: I thank thee for it; and heaven forbid That kings should let their ears hear their faults hid! Fit counsellor and servant for a prince, Who by thy wisdom makest a prince thy servant, What wouldst thou have me do?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: To bear with patience Such griefs as you yourself do lay upon yourself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Thou speak'st like a physician, Helicanus, That minister'st a potion unto me That thou wouldst tremble to receive thyself. Attend me, then: I went to Antioch, Where as thou know'st, against the face of death, I sought the purchase of a glorious beauty. From whence an issue I might propagate, Are arms to princes, and bring joys to subjects. Her face was to mine eye beyond all wonder; The rest--hark in thine ear--as black as incest: Which by my knowledge found, the sinful father Seem'd not to strike, but smooth: but thou know'st this, 'Tis time to fear when tyrants seem to kiss. Such fear so grew in me, I hither fled, Under the covering of a careful night, Who seem'd my good protector; and, being here, Bethought me what was past, what might succeed. I knew him tyrannous; and tyrants' fears Decrease not, but grow faster than the years: And should he doubt it, as no doubt he doth, That I should open to the listening air How many worthy princes' bloods were shed, To keep his bed of blackness unlaid ope, To lop that doubt, he'll fill this land with arms, And make pretence of wrong that I have done him: When all, for mine, if I may call offence, Must feel war's blow, who spares not innocence: Which love to all, of which thyself art one, Who now reprovest me for it,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Alas, sir!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Drew sleep out of mine eyes, blood from my cheeks, Musings into my mind, with thousand doubts How I might stop this tempest ere it came; And finding little comfort to relieve them, I thought it princely charity to grieve them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Well, my lord, since you have given me leave to speak. Freely will I speak. Antiochus you fear, And justly too, I think, you fear the tyrant, Who either by public war or private treason Will take away your life. Therefore, my lord, go travel for a while, Till that his rage and anger be forgot, Or till the Destinies do cut his thread of life. Your rule direct to any; if to me. Day serves not light more faithful than I'll be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: I do not doubt thy faith; But should he wrong my liberties in my absence?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: We'll mingle our bloods together in the earth, From whence we had our being and our birth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Tyre. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Tyre, I now look from thee then, and to Tarsus Intend my travel, where I'll hear from thee; And by whose letters I'll dispose myself. The care I had and have of subjects' good On thee I lay whose wisdom's strength can bear it. I'll take thy word for faith, not ask thine oath: Who shuns not to break one will sure crack both: But in our orbs we'll live so round and safe, That time of both this truth shall ne'er convince, Thou show'dst a subject's shine, I a true prince.

scene.title: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: So, this is Tyre, and this the court. Here must I kill King Pericles; and if I do it not, I am sure to be hanged at home: 'tis dangerous. Well, I perceive he was a wise fellow, and had good discretion, that, being bid to ask what he would of the king, desired he might know none of his secrets: now do I see he had some reason for't; for if a king bid a man be a villain, he's bound by the indenture of his oath to be one! Hush! here come the lords of Tyre.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: You shall not need, my fellow peers of Tyre, Further to question me of your king's departure: His seal'd commission, left in trust with me, Doth speak sufficiently he's gone to travel.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: How! the king gone!

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: If further yet you will be satisfied, Why, as it were unlicensed of your loves, He would depart, I'll give some light unto you. Being at Antioch--

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: What from Antioch?

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: Royal Antiochus--on what cause I know not-- Took some displeasure at him; at least he judged so: And doubting lest that he had err'd or sinn'd, To show his sorrow, he'ld correct himself; So puts himself unto the shipman's toil, With whom each minute threatens life or death.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: Well, I perceive I shall not be hang'd now, although I would; But since he's gone, the king's seas must please: He 'scaped the land, to perish at the sea. I'll present myself. Peace to the lords of Tyre!

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: Lord Thaliard from Antiochus is welcome.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: From him I come With message unto princely Pericles; But since my landing I have understood Your lord has betook himself to unknown travels, My message must return from whence it came.

speech.stagedir: Enter HELICANUS and ESCANES, with other Lords of Tyre
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tyre. An ante-chamber in the palace.
speech.text: We have no reason to desire it, Commended to our master, not to us: Yet, ere you shall depart, this we desire, As friends to Antioch, we may feast in Tyre.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: My Dionyza, shall we rest us here, And by relating tales of others' griefs, See if 'twill teach us to forget our own?

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: O Dionyza, Who wanteth food, and will not say he wants it, Or can conceal his hunger till he famish? Our tongues and sorrows do sound deep Our woes into the air; our eyes do weep, Till tongues fetch breath that may proclaim them louder; That, if heaven slumber while their creatures want, They may awake their helps to comfort them. I'll then discourse our woes, felt several years, And wanting breath to speak help me with tears.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: I'll do my best, sir.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: This Tarsus, o'er which I have the government, A city on whom plenty held full hand, For riches strew'd herself even in the streets; Whose towers bore heads so high they kiss'd the clouds, And strangers ne'er beheld but wondered at; Whose men and dames so jetted and adorn'd, Like one another's glass to trim them by: Their tables were stored full, to glad the sight, And not so much to feed on as delight; All poverty was scorn'd, and pride so great, The name of help grew odious to repeat.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: O, 'tis too true.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: But see what heaven can do! By this our change, These mouths, who but of late, earth, sea, and air, Were all too little to content and please, Although they gave their creatures in abundance, As houses are defiled for want of use, They are now starved for want of exercise: Those palates who, not yet two summers younger, Must have inventions to delight the taste, Would now be glad of bread, and beg for it: Those mothers who, to nousle up their babes, Thought nought too curious, are ready now To eat those little darlings whom they loved. So sharp are hunger's teeth, that man and wife Draw lots who first shall die to lengthen life: Here stands a lord, and there a lady weeping; Here many sink, yet those which see them fall Have scarce strength left to give them burial. Is not this true?

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Our cheeks and hollow eyes do witness it.

speech.stagedir: Enter CLEON, the governor of Tarsus, with DIONYZA, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: O, let those cities that of plenty's cup And her prosperities so largely taste, With their superfluous riots, hear these tears! The misery of Tarsus may be theirs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Where's the lord governor?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Here. Speak out thy sorrows which thou bring'st in haste, For comfort is too far for us to expect.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: We have descried, upon our neighbouring shore, A portly sail of ships make hitherward.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: I thought as much. One sorrow never comes but brings an heir, That may succeed as his inheritor; And so in ours: some neighbouring nation, Taking advantage of our misery, Hath stuff'd these hollow vessels with their power, To beat us down, the which are down already; And make a conquest of unhappy me, Whereas no glory's got to overcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: That's the least fear; for, by the semblance Of their white flags display'd, they bring us peace, And come to us as favourers, not as foes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Thou speak'st like him's untutor'd to repeat: Who makes the fairest show means most deceit. But bring they what they will and what they can, What need we fear? The ground's the lowest, and we are half way there. Go tell their general we attend him here, To know for what he comes, and whence he comes, And what he craves.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: I go, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Welcome is peace, if he on peace consist; If wars, we are unable to resist.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Lord governor, for so we hear you are, Let not our ships and number of our men Be like a beacon fired to amaze your eyes. We have heard your miseries as far as Tyre, And seen the desolation of your streets: Nor come we to add sorrow to your tears, But to relieve them of their heavy load; And these our ships, you happily may think Are like the Trojan horse was stuff'd within With bloody veins, expecting overthrow, Are stored with corn to make your needy bread, And give them life whom hunger starved half dead.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: The gods of Greece protect you! And we'll pray for you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Arise, I pray you, rise: We do not look for reverence, but to love, And harbourage for ourself, our ships, and men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: The which when any shall not gratify, Or pay you with unthankfulness in thought, Be it our wives, our children, or ourselves, The curse of heaven and men succeed their evils! Till when,--the which I hope shall ne'er be seen,-- Your grace is welcome to our town and us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tarsus. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Which welcome we'll accept; feast here awhile, Until our stars that frown lend us a smile.

scene.title: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Yet cease your ire, you angry stars of heaven! Wind, rain, and thunder, remember, earthly man Is but a substance that must yield to you; And I, as fits my nature, do obey you: Alas, the sea hath cast me on the rocks, Wash'd me from shore to shore, and left me breath Nothing to think on but ensuing death: Let it suffice the greatness of your powers To have bereft a prince of all his fortunes; And having thrown him from your watery grave, Here to have death in peace is all he'll crave.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: What, ho, Pilch!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Ha, come and bring away the nets!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: What, Patch-breech, I say!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: What say you, master?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Look how thou stirrest now! come away, or I'll fetch thee with a wanion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Faith, master, I am thinking of the poor men that were cast away before us even now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Alas, poor souls, it grieved my heart to hear what pitiful cries they made to us to help them, when, well-a-day, we could scarce help ourselves.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Nay, master, said not I as much when I saw the porpus how he bounced and tumbled? they say they're half fish, half flesh: a plague on them, they ne'er come but I look to be washed. Master, I marvel how the fishes live in the sea.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Why, as men do a-land; the great ones eat up the little ones: I can compare our rich misers to nothing so fitly as to a whale; a' plays and tumbles, driving the poor fry before him, and at last devours them all at a mouthful: such whales have I heard on o' the land, who never leave gaping till they've swallowed the whole parish, church, steeple, bells, and all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: A pretty moral.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: But, master, if I had been the sexton, I would have been that day in the belfry.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Why, man?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Because he should have swallowed me too: and when I had been in his belly, I would have kept such a jangling of the bells, that he should never have left, till he cast bells, steeple, church, and parish up again. But if the good King Simonides were of my mind,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Simonides!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: We would purge the land of these drones, that rob the bee of her honey.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: How from the finny subject of the sea These fishers tell the infirmities of men; And from their watery empire recollect All that may men approve or men detect! Peace be at your labour, honest fishermen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Honest! good fellow, what's that? If it be a day fits you, search out of the calendar, and nobody look after it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: May see the sea hath cast upon your coast.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: What a drunken knave was the sea to cast thee in our way!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: A man whom both the waters and the wind, In that vast tennis-court, have made the ball For them to play upon, entreats you pity him: He asks of you, that never used to beg.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: No, friend, cannot you beg? Here's them in our country Greece gets more with begging than we can do with working.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Canst thou catch any fishes, then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: I never practised it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Nay, then thou wilt starve, sure; for here's nothing to be got now-a-days, unless thou canst fish for't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: What I have been I have forgot to know; But what I am, want teaches me to think on: A man throng'd up with cold: my veins are chill, And have no more of life than may suffice To give my tongue that heat to ask your help; Which if you shall refuse, when I am dead, For that I am a man, pray see me buried.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Die quoth-a? Now gods forbid! I have a gown here; come, put it on; keep thee warm. Now, afore me, a handsome fellow! Come, thou shalt go home, and we'll have flesh for holidays, fish for fasting-days, and moreo'er puddings and flap-jacks, and thou shalt be welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: I thank you, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Hark you, my friend; you said you could not beg.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: I did but crave.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: But crave! Then I'll turn craver too, and so I shall 'scape whipping.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Why, are all your beggars whipped, then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: O, not all, my friend, not all; for if all your beggars were whipped, I would wish no better office than to be beadle. But, master, I'll go draw up the net.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: How well this honest mirth becomes their labour!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Hark you, sir, do you know where ye are?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Not well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Why, I'll tell you: this is called Pentapolis, and our king the good Simonides.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: The good King Simonides, do you call him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Ay, sir; and he deserves so to be called for his peaceable reign and good government.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: He is a happy king, since he gains from his subjects the name of good by his government. How far is his court distant from this shore?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Marry, sir, half a day's journey: and I'll tell you, he hath a fair daughter, and to-morrow is her birth-day; and there are princes and knights come from all parts of the world to just and tourney for her love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Were my fortunes equal to my desires, I could wish to make one there.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: O, sir, things must be as they may; and what a man cannot get, he may lawfully deal for--his wife's soul.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Help, master, help! here's a fish hangs in the net, like a poor man's right in the law; 'twill hardly come out. Ha! bots on't, 'tis come at last, and 'tis turned to a rusty armour.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: An armour, friends! I pray you, let me see it. Thanks, fortune, yet, that, after all my crosses, Thou givest me somewhat to repair myself; And though it was mine own, part of my heritage, Which my dead father did bequeath to me. With this strict charge, even as he left his life, 'Keep it, my Pericles; it hath been a shield Twixt me and death;'--and pointed to this brace;-- 'For that it saved me, keep it; in like necessity-- The which the gods protect thee from!--may defend thee.' It kept where I kept, I so dearly loved it; Till the rough seas, that spare not any man, Took it in rage, though calm'd have given't again: I thank thee for't: my shipwreck now's no ill, Since I have here my father's gift in's will.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: What mean you, sir?

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Why, wilt thou tourney for the lady?

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: I'll show the virtue I have borne in arms.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Why, do 'e take it, and the gods give thee good on't!

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Ay, but hark you, my friend; 'twas we that made up this garment through the rough seams of the waters: there are certain condolements, certain vails. I hope, sir, if you thrive, you'll remember from whence you had it.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Believe 't, I will. By your furtherance I am clothed in steel; And, spite of all the rapture of the sea, This jewel holds his building on my arm: Unto thy value I will mount myself Upon a courser, whose delightful steps Shall make the gazer joy to see him tread. Only, my friend, I yet am unprovided Of a pair of bases.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: We'll sure provide: thou shalt have my best gown to make thee a pair; and I'll bring thee to the court myself.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter Second and Third Fishermen, drawing up a net
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Pentapolis. An open place by the sea-side.
speech.text: Then honour be but a goal to my will, This day I'll rise, or else add ill to ill.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: Are the knights ready to begin the triumph?

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: They are, my liege; And stay your coming to present themselves.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: Return them, we are ready; and our daughter, In honour of whose birth these triumphs are, Sits here, like beauty's child, whom nature gat For men to see, and seeing wonder at.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: It pleaseth you, my royal father, to express My commendations great, whose merit's less.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: It's fit it should be so; for princes are A model which heaven makes like to itself: As jewels lose their glory if neglected, So princes their renowns if not respected. 'Tis now your honour, daughter, to explain The labour of each knight in his device.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: Which, to preserve mine honour, I'll perform.

speech.stagedir: Enter a Knight; he passes over, and his Squire presents his shield to the Princess
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: Who is the first that doth prefer himself?

speech.stagedir: Enter a Knight; he passes over, and his Squire presents his shield to the Princess
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: A knight of Sparta, my renowned father; And the device he bears upon his shield Is a black Ethiope reaching at the sun The word, 'Lux tua vita mihi.'

speech.stagedir: Enter a Knight; he passes over, and his Squire presents his shield to the Princess
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: He loves you well that holds his life of you. Who is the second that presents himself?

speech.stagedir: Enter a Knight; he passes over, and his Squire presents his shield to the Princess
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: And what's the third?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: What is the fourth?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: A burning torch that's turned upside down; The word, 'Quod me alit, me extinguit.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: Which shows that beauty hath his power and will, Which can as well inflame as it can kill.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.

speech.stagedir: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: And what's The sixth and last, the which the knight himself With such a graceful courtesy deliver'd?

speech.stagedir: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.

speech.stagedir: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.

speech.stagedir: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: He had need mean better than his outward show Can any way speak in his just commend; For by his rusty outside he appears To have practised more the whipstock than the lance.

speech.stagedir: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: He well may be a stranger, for he comes To an honour'd triumph strangely furnished.

speech.stagedir: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: And on set purpose let his armour rust Until this day, to scour it in the dust.

speech.stagedir: The Sixth Knight, PERICLES, passes over
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. A public way or platform leading to the lists. A pavilion by the side of it for the reception of King, Princess, Lords, &c.
speech.text: Opinion's but a fool, that makes us scan The outward habit by the inward man. But stay, the knights are coming: we will withdraw Into the gallery.

scene.title: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Knights, To say you're welcome were superfluous. To place upon the volume of your deeds, As in a title-page, your worth in arms, Were more than you expect, or more than's fit, Since every worth in show commends itself. Prepare for mirth, for mirth becomes a feast: You are princes and my guests.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: 'Tis more by fortune, lady, than by merit.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Call it by what you will, the day is yours; And here, I hope, is none that envies it. In framing an artist, art hath thus decreed, To make some good, but others to exceed; And you are her labour'd scholar. Come, queen o' the feast,-- For, daughter, so you are,--here take your place: Marshal the rest, as they deserve their grace.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: We are honour'd much by good Simonides.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Your presence glads our days: honour we love; For who hates honour hates the gods above.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Sir, yonder is your place.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Some other is more fit.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Contend not, sir; for we are gentlemen That neither in our hearts nor outward eyes Envy the great nor do the low despise.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: You are right courteous knights.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Sit, sir, sit.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: By Jove, I wonder, that is king of thoughts, These cates resist me, she but thought upon.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: By Juno, that is queen of marriage, All viands that I eat do seem unsavoury. Wishing him my meat. Sure, he's a gallant gentleman.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: To me he seems like diamond to glass.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Yon king's to me like to my father's picture, Which tells me in that glory once he was; Had princes sit, like stars, about his throne, And he the sun, for them to reverence; None that beheld him, but, like lesser lights, Did vail their crowns to his supremacy: Where now his son's like a glow-worm in the night, The which hath fire in darkness, none in light: Whereby I see that Time's the king of men, He's both their parent, and he is their grave, And gives them what he will, not what they crave.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: What, are you merry, knights?

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Who can be other in this royal presence?

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Here, with a cup that's stored unto the brim,-- As you do love, fill to your mistress' lips,-- We drink this health to you.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: We thank your grace.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Yet pause awhile: Yon knight doth sit too melancholy, As if the entertainment in our court Had not a show might countervail his worth. Note it not you, Thaisa?

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: What is it To me, my father?

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: O, attend, my daughter: Princes in this should live like gods above, Who freely give to every one that comes To honour them: And princes not doing so are like to gnats, Which make a sound, but kill'd are wonder'd at. Therefore to make his entrance more sweet, Here, say we drink this standing-bowl of wine to him.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Alas, my father, it befits not me Unto a stranger knight to be so bold: He may my proffer take for an offence, Since men take women's gifts for impudence.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: How! Do as I bid you, or you'll move me else.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Now, by the gods, he could not please me better.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: And furthermore tell him, we desire to know of him, Of whence he is, his name and parentage.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: The king my father, sir, has drunk to you.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: I thank him.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Wishing it so much blood unto your life.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: I thank both him and you, and pledge him freely.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: And further he desires to know of you, Of whence you are, your name and parentage.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: He thanks your grace; names himself Pericles, A gentleman of Tyre, Who only by misfortune of the seas Bereft of ships and men, cast on this shore.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: Now, by the gods, I pity his misfortune, And will awake him from his melancholy. Come, gentlemen, we sit too long on trifles, And waste the time, which looks for other revels. Even in your armours, as you are address'd, Will very well become a soldier's dance. I will not have excuse, with saying this Loud music is too harsh for ladies' heads, Since they love men in arms as well as beds. So, this was well ask'd,'twas so well perform'd. Come, sir; Here is a lady that wants breathing too: And I have heard, you knights of Tyre Are excellent in making ladies trip; And that their measures are as excellent.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: In those that practise them they are, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: O, that's as much as you would be denied Of your fair courtesy. Unclasp, unclasp: Thanks, gentlemen, to all; all have done well. But you the best. Pages and lights, to conduct These knights unto their several lodgings! Yours, sir, We have given order to be next our own.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.
speech.text: I am at your grace's pleasure.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, THAISA, Lords, Attendants, and Knights, from tilting
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. A hall of state: a banquet prepared.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: No, Escanes, know this of me, Antiochus from incest lived not free: For which, the most high gods not minding longer To withhold the vengeance that they had in store, Due to this heinous capital offence, Even in the height and pride of all his glory, When he was seated in a chariot Of an inestimable value, and his daughter with him, A fire from heaven came and shrivell'd up Their bodies, even to loathing; for they so stunk, That all those eyes adored them ere their fall Scorn now their hand should give them burial.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: 'Twas very strange.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: And yet but justice; for though This king were great, his greatness was no guard To bar heaven's shaft, but sin had his reward.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: 'Tis very true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: See, not a man in private conference Or council has respect with him but he.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: It shall no longer grieve without reproof.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: And cursed be he that will not second it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Follow me, then. Lord Helicane, a word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: With me? and welcome: happy day, my lords.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Know that our griefs are risen to the top, And now at length they overflow their banks.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Your griefs! for what? wrong not your prince you love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Whose death indeed's the strongest in our censure: And knowing this kingdom is without a head,-- Like goodly buildings left without a roof Soon fall to ruin,--your noble self, That best know how to rule and how to reign, We thus submit unto,--our sovereign.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Live, noble Helicane!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: For honour's cause, forbear your suffrages: If that you love Prince Pericles, forbear. Take I your wish, I leap into the seas, Where's hourly trouble for a minute's ease. A twelvemonth longer, let me entreat you to Forbear the absence of your king: If in which time expired, he not return, I shall with aged patience bear your yoke. But if I cannot win you to this love, Go search like nobles, like noble subjects, And in your search spend your adventurous worth; Whom if you find, and win unto return, You shall like diamonds sit about his crown.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
SCENE IV. Tyre. A room in the Governor's house.
speech.text: Then you love us, we you, and we'll clasp hands: When peers thus knit, a kingdom ever stands.

scene.title: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, reading a letter, at one door: the Knights meet him
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Good morrow to the good Simonides.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, reading a letter, at one door: the Knights meet him
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Knights, from my daughter this I let you know, That for this twelvemonth she'll not undertake A married life. Her reason to herself is only known, Which yet from her by no means can I get.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, reading a letter, at one door: the Knights meet him
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: May we not get access to her, my lord?

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, reading a letter, at one door: the Knights meet him
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: 'Faith, by no means; she has so strictly tied Her to her chamber, that 'tis impossible. One twelve moons more she'll wear Diana's livery; This by the eye of Cynthia hath she vow'd And on her virgin honour will not break it.

speech.stagedir: Enter SIMONIDES, reading a letter, at one door: the Knights meet him
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Loath to bid farewell, we take our leaves.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: So, They are well dispatch'd; now to my daughter's letter: She tells me here, she'd wed the stranger knight, Or never more to view nor day nor light. 'Tis well, mistress; your choice agrees with mine; I like that well: nay, how absolute she's in't, Not minding whether I dislike or no! Well, I do commend her choice; And will no longer have it be delay'd. Soft! here he comes: I must dissemble it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: All fortune to the good Simonides!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: To you as much, sir! I am beholding to you For your sweet music this last night: I do Protest my ears were never better fed With such delightful pleasing harmony.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: It is your grace's pleasure to commend; Not my desert.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Sir, you are music's master.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: The worst of all her scholars, my good lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Let me ask you one thing: What do you think of my daughter, sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: A most virtuous princess.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: And she is fair too, is she not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: As a fair day in summer, wondrous fair.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: I am unworthy for her schoolmaster.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: She thinks not so; peruse this writing else.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: What's here? A letter, that she loves the knight of Tyre! 'Tis the king's subtlety to have my life. O, seek not to entrap me, gracious lord, A stranger and distressed gentleman, That never aim'd so high to love your daughter, But bent all offices to honour her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Thou hast bewitch'd my daughter, and thou art A villain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: By the gods, I have not: Never did thought of mine levy offence; Nor never did my actions yet commence A deed might gain her love or your displeasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Traitor, thou liest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Traitor!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Ay, traitor.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Even in his throat--unless it be the king-- That calls me traitor, I return the lie.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Now, by the gods, I do applaud his courage.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: My actions are as noble as my thoughts, That never relish'd of a base descent. I came unto your court for honour's cause, And not to be a rebel to her state; And he that otherwise accounts of me, This sword shall prove he's honour's enemy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: No? Here comes my daughter, she can witness it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Then, as you are as virtuous as fair, Resolve your angry father, if my tongue Did ere solicit, or my hand subscribe To any syllable that made love to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Why, sir, say if you had, Who takes offence at that would make me glad?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Yea, mistress, are you so peremptory? I am glad on't with all my heart.-- I'll tame you; I'll bring you in subjection. Will you, not having my consent, Bestow your love and your affections Upon a stranger? who, for aught I know, May be, nor can I think the contrary, As great in blood as I myself.-- Therefore hear you, mistress; either frame Your will to mine,--and you, sir, hear you, Either be ruled by me, or I will make you-- Man and wife: Nay, come, your hands and lips must seal it too: And being join'd, I'll thus your hopes destroy; And for a further grief,--God give you joy!-- What, are you both pleased?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Yes, if you love me, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Even as my life, or blood that fosters it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: What, are you both agreed?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: Yes, if it please your majesty.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Pentapolis. A room in the palace.
speech.text: It pleaseth me so well, that I will see you wed; And then with what haste you can get you to bed.

scene.title: SCENE I

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Thou god of this great vast, rebuke these surges, Which wash both heaven and hell; and thou, that hast Upon the winds command, bind them in brass, Having call'd them from the deep! O, still Thy deafening, dreadful thunders; gently quench Thy nimble, sulphurous flashes! O, how, Lychorida, How does my queen? Thou stormest venomously; Wilt thou spit all thyself? The seaman's whistle Is as a whisper in the ears of death, Unheard. Lychorida!--Lucina, O Divinest patroness, and midwife gentle To those that cry by night, convey thy deity Aboard our dancing boat; make swift the pangs Of my queen's travails! Now, Lychorida!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Here is a thing too young for such a place, Who, if it had conceit, would die, as I Am like to do: take in your arms this piece Of your dead queen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: How, how, Lychorida!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Patience, good sir; do not assist the storm. Here's all that is left living of your queen, A little daughter: for the sake of it, Be manly, and take comfort.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: O you gods! Why do you make us love your goodly gifts, And snatch them straight away? We here below Recall not what we give, and therein may Use honour with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Patience, good sir, Even for this charge.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Now, mild may be thy life! For a more blustrous birth had never babe: Quiet and gentle thy conditions! for Thou art the rudeliest welcome to this world That ever was prince's child. Happy what follows! Thou hast as chiding a nativity As fire, air, water, earth, and heaven can make, To herald thee from the womb: even at the first Thy loss is more than can thy portage quit, With all thou canst find here. Now, the good gods Throw their best eyes upon't!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: What courage, sir? God save you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Courage enough: I do not fear the flaw; It hath done to me the worst. Yet, for the love Of this poor infant, this fresh-new sea-farer, I would it would be quiet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Slack the bolins there! Thou wilt not, wilt thou? Blow, and split thyself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: But sea-room, an the brine and cloudy billow kiss the moon, I care not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Sir, your queen must overboard: the sea works high, the wind is loud, and will not lie till the ship be cleared of the dead.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: That's your superstition.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Pardon us, sir; with us at sea it hath been still observed: and we are strong in custom. Therefore briefly yield her; for she must overboard straight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: As you think meet. Most wretched queen!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Here she lies, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: A terrible childbed hast thou had, my dear; No light, no fire: the unfriendly elements Forgot thee utterly: nor have I time To give thee hallow'd to thy grave, but straight Must cast thee, scarcely coffin'd, in the ooze; Where, for a monument upon thy bones, And e'er-remaining lamps, the belching whale And humming water must o'erwhelm thy corpse, Lying with simple shells. O Lychorida, Bid Nestor bring me spices, ink and paper, My casket and my jewels; and bid Nicander Bring me the satin coffer: lay the babe Upon the pillow: hie thee, whiles I say A priestly farewell to her: suddenly, woman.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Sir, we have a chest beneath the hatches, caulked and bitumed ready.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: I thank thee. Mariner, say what coast is this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: We are near Tarsus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: Thither, gentle mariner. Alter thy course for Tyre. When canst thou reach it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: By break of day, if the wind cease.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I
speech.text: O, make for Tarsus! There will I visit Cleon, for the babe Cannot hold out to Tyrus: there I'll leave it At careful nursing. Go thy ways, good mariner: I'll bring the body presently.

scene.title: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter CERIMON, with a Servant, and some Persons who have been shipwrecked
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Philemon, ho!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Doth my lord call?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Get fire and meat for these poor men: 'T has been a turbulent and stormy night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: I have been in many; but such a night as this, Till now, I ne'er endured.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Your master will be dead ere you return; There's nothing can be minister'd to nature That can recover him. Give this to the 'pothecary, And tell me how it works.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Good morrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Good morrow to your lordship.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Gentlemen, Why do you stir so early?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Sir, Our lodgings, standing bleak upon the sea, Shook as the earth did quake; The very principals did seem to rend, And all-to topple: pure surprise and fear Made me to quit the house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: That is the cause we trouble you so early; 'Tis not our husbandry.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: O, you say well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: But I much marvel that your lordship, having Rich tire about you, should at these early hours Shake off the golden slumber of repose. 'Tis most strange, Nature should be so conversant with pain, Being thereto not compell'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: I hold it ever, Virtue and cunning were endowments greater Than nobleness and riches: careless heirs May the two latter darken and expend; But immortality attends the former. Making a man a god. 'Tis known, I ever Have studied physic, through which secret art, By turning o'er authorities, I have, Together with my practise, made familiar To me and to my aid the blest infusions That dwell in vegetives, in metals, stones; And I can speak of the disturbances That nature works, and of her cures; which doth give me A more content in course of true delight Than to be thirsty after tottering honour, Or tie my treasure up in silken bags, To please the fool and death.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Your honour has through Ephesus pour'd forth Your charity, and hundreds call themselves Your creatures, who by you have been restored: And not your knowledge, your personal pain, but even Your purse, still open, hath built Lord Cerimon Such strong renown as time shall ne'er decay.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: So; lift there.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: What is that?

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Sir, even now Did the sea toss upon our shore this chest: 'Tis of some wreck.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Set 't down, let's look upon't.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: 'Tis like a coffin, sir.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Whate'er it be, 'Tis wondrous heavy. Wrench it open straight: If the sea's stomach be o'ercharged with gold, 'Tis a good constraint of fortune it belches upon us.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: 'Tis so, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: How close 'tis caulk'd and bitumed! Did the sea cast it up?

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: I never saw so huge a billow, sir, As toss'd it upon shore.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Wrench it open; Soft! it smells most sweetly in my sense.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: A delicate odour.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: As ever hit my nostril. So, up with it. O you most potent gods! what's here? a corse!

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Most strange!

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Shrouded in cloth of state; balm'd and entreasured With full bags of spices! A passport too! Apollo, perfect me in the characters! 'Here I give to understand, If e'er this coffin drive a-land, I, King Pericles, have lost This queen, worth all our mundane cost. Who finds her, give her burying; She was the daughter of a king: Besides this treasure for a fee, The gods requite his charity!' If thou livest, Pericles, thou hast a heart That even cracks for woe! This chanced tonight.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Most likely, sir.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Nay, certainly to-night; For look how fresh she looks! They were too rough That threw her in the sea. Make a fire within: Fetch hither all my boxes in my closet. Death may usurp on nature many hours, And yet the fire of life kindle again The o'erpress'd spirits. I heard of an Egyptian That had nine hours lien dead, Who was by good appliance recovered. Well said, well said; the fire and cloths. The rough and woeful music that we have, Cause it to sound, beseech you. The viol once more: how thou stirr'st, thou block! The music there!--I pray you, give her air. Gentlemen. This queen will live: nature awakes; a warmth Breathes out of her: she hath not been entranced Above five hours: see how she gins to blow Into life's flower again!

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: The heavens, Through you, increase our wonder and set up Your fame forever.

speech.stagedir: Enter two or three Servants with a chest
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: She is alive; behold, Her eyelids, cases to those heavenly jewels Which Pericles hath lost, Begin to part their fringes of bright gold; The diamonds of a most praised water Do appear, to make the world twice rich. Live, And make us weep to hear your fate, fair creature, Rare as you seem to be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: O dear Diana, Where am I? Where's my lord? What world is this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Is not this strange?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Most rare.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Hush, my gentle neighbours! Lend me your hands; to the next chamber bear her. Get linen: now this matter must be look'd to, For her relapse is mortal. Come, come; And AEsculapius guide us!

scene.title: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Most honour'd Cleon, I must needs be gone; My twelve months are expired, and Tyrus stands In a litigious peace. You, and your lady, Take from my heart all thankfulness! The gods Make up the rest upon you!

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Your shafts of fortune, though they hurt you mortally, Yet glance full wanderingly on us.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: O your sweet queen! That the strict fates had pleased you had brought her hither, To have bless'd mine eyes with her!

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: We cannot but obey The powers above us. Could I rage and roar As doth the sea she lies in, yet the end Must be as 'tis. My gentle babe Marina, whom, For she was born at sea, I have named so, here I charge your charity withal, leaving her The infant of your care; beseeching you To give her princely training, that she may be Manner'd as she is born.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Fear not, my lord, but think Your grace, that fed my country with your corn, For which the people's prayers still fall upon you, Must in your child be thought on.
