If neglection Should therein make me vile, the common body, By you relieved, would force me to my duty: But if to that my nature need a spur, The gods revenge it upon me and mine, To the end of generation!

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: I believe you; Your honour and your goodness teach me to't, Without your vows. Till she be married, madam, By bright Diana, whom we honour, all Unscissor'd shall this hair of mine remain, Though I show ill in't. So I take my leave. Good madam, make me blessed in your care In bringing up my child.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: I have one myself, Who shall not be more dear to my respect Than yours, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Madam, my thanks and prayers.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: We'll bring your grace e'en to the edge o' the shore, Then give you up to the mask'd Neptune and The gentlest winds of heaven.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, CLEON, DIONYZA, and LYCHORIDA with MARINA in her arms
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: I will embrace Your offer. Come, dearest madam. O, no tears, Lychorida, no tears: Look to your little mistress, on whose grace You may depend hereafter. Come, my lord.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Madam, this letter, and some certain jewels, Lay with you in your coffer: which are now At your command. Know you the character?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: It is my lord's. That I was shipp'd at sea, I well remember, Even on my eaning time; but whether there Deliver'd, by the holy gods, I cannot rightly say. But since King Pericles, My wedded lord, I ne'er shall see again, A vestal livery will I take me to, And never more have joy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: Madam, if this you purpose as ye speak, Diana's temple is not distant far, Where you may abide till your date expire. Moreover, if you please, a niece of mine Shall there attend you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Ephesus. A room in CERIMON's house.
speech.text: My recompense is thanks, that's all; Yet my good will is great, though the gift small.

scene.title: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Thy oath remember; thou hast sworn to do't: 'Tis but a blow, which never shall be known. Thou canst not do a thing in the world so soon, To yield thee so much profit. Let not conscience, Which is but cold, inflaming love i' thy bosom, Inflame too nicely; nor let pity, which Even women have cast off, melt thee, but be A soldier to thy purpose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: I will do't; but yet she is a goodly creature.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: The fitter, then, the gods should have her. Here she comes weeping for her only mistress' death. Thou art resolved?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: I am resolved.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: No, I will rob Tellus of her weed, To strew thy green with flowers: the yellows, blues, The purple violets, and marigolds, Shall as a carpet hang upon thy grave, While summer-days do last. Ay me! poor maid, Born in a tempest, when my mother died, This world to me is like a lasting storm, Whirring me from my friends.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: How now, Marina! why do you keep alone? How chance my daughter is not with you? Do not Consume your blood with sorrowing: you have A nurse of me. Lord, how your favour's changed With this unprofitable woe! Come, give me your flowers, ere the sea mar it. Walk with Leonine; the air is quick there, And it pierces and sharpens the stomach. Come, Leonine, take her by the arm, walk with her.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: No, I pray you; I'll not bereave you of your servant.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Come, come; I love the king your father, and yourself, With more than foreign heart. We every day Expect him here: when he shall come and find Our paragon to all reports thus blasted, He will repent the breadth of his great voyage; Blame both my lord and me, that we have taken No care to your best courses. Go, I pray you, Walk, and be cheerful once again; reserve That excellent complexion, which did steal The eyes of young and old. Care not for me I can go home alone.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Well, I will go; But yet I have no desire to it.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Come, come, I know 'tis good for you. Walk half an hour, Leonine, at the least: Remember what I have said.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: I warrant you, madam.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: I'll leave you, my sweet lady, for a while: Pray, walk softly, do not heat your blood: What! I must have a care of you.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: My thanks, sweet madam. Is this wind westerly that blows?

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: South-west.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: When I was born, the wind was north.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Was't so?

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: My father, as nurse said, did never fear, But cried 'Good seaman!' to the sailors, galling His kingly hands, haling ropes; And, clasping to the mast, endured a sea That almost burst the deck.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: When was this?

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: When I was born: Never was waves nor wind more violent; And from the ladder-tackle washes off A canvas-climber. 'Ha!' says one, 'wilt out?' And with a dropping industry they skip From stem to stern: the boatswain whistles, and The master calls, and trebles their confusion.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Come, say your prayers.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: What mean you?

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: If you require a little space for prayer, I grant it: pray; but be not tedious, For the gods are quick of ear, and I am sworn To do my work with haste.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Why will you kill me?

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: To satisfy my lady.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Why would she have me kill'd? Now, as I can remember, by my troth, I never did her hurt in all my life: I never spake bad word, nor did ill turn To any living creature: believe me, la, I never kill'd a mouse, nor hurt a fly: I trod upon a worm against my will, But I wept for it. How have I offended, Wherein my death might yield her any profit, Or my life imply her any danger?

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: My commission Is not to reason of the deed, but do it.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: You will not do't for all the world, I hope. You are well favour'd, and your looks foreshow You have a gentle heart. I saw you lately, When you caught hurt in parting two that fought: Good sooth, it show'd well in you: do so now: Your lady seeks my life; come you between, And save poor me, the weaker.

speech.stagedir: Enter MARINA, with a basket of flowers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: I am sworn, And will dispatch.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Hold, villain!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: A prize! a prize!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: Half-part, mates, half-part. Come, let's have her aboard suddenly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Tarsus. An open place near the sea-shore.
speech.text: These roguing thieves serve the great pirate Valdes; And they have seized Marina. Let her go: There's no hope she will return. I'll swear she's dead, And thrown into the sea. But I'll see further: Perhaps they will but please themselves upon her, Not carry her aboard. If she remain, Whom they have ravish'd must by me be slain.

scene.title: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Boult!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Search the market narrowly; Mytilene is full of gallants. We lost too much money this mart by being too wenchless.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: We were never so much out of creatures. We have but poor three, and they can do no more than they can do; and they with continual action are even as good as rotten.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Therefore let's have fresh ones, whate'er we pay for them. If there be not a conscience to be used in every trade, we shall never prosper.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Thou sayest true: 'tis not our bringing up of poor bastards,--as, I think, I have brought up some eleven--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Ay, to eleven; and brought them down again. But shall I search the market?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: What else, man? The stuff we have, a strong wind will blow it to pieces, they are so pitifully sodden.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Thou sayest true; they're too unwholesome, o' conscience. The poor Transylvanian is dead, that lay with the little baggage.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Ay, she quickly pooped him; she made him roast-meat for worms. But I'll go search the market.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Three or four thousand chequins were as pretty a proportion to live quietly, and so give over.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Why to give over, I pray you? is it a shame to get when we are old?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: O, our credit comes not in like the commodity, nor the commodity wages not with the danger: therefore, if in our youths we could pick up some pretty estate, 'twere not amiss to keep our door hatched. Besides, the sore terms we stand upon with the gods will be strong with us for giving over.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Come, other sorts offend as well as we.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: As well as we! ay, and better too; we offend worse. Neither is our profession any trade; it's no calling. But here comes Boult.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Come your ways. My masters, you say she's a virgin?

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: O, sir, we doubt it not.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Master, I have gone through for this piece, you see: if you like her, so; if not, I have lost my earnest.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Boult, has she any qualities?

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: She has a good face, speaks well, and has excellent good clothes: there's no further necessity of qualities can make her be refused.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: What's her price, Boult?

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: I cannot be bated one doit of a thousand pieces.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter BOULT, with the Pirates and MARINA
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Well, follow me, my masters, you shall have your money presently. Wife, take her in; instruct her what she has to do, that she may not be raw in her entertainment.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Boult, take you the marks of her, the colour of her hair, complexion, height, age, with warrant of her virginity; and cry 'He that will give most shall have her first.' Such a maidenhead were no cheap thing, if men were as they have been. Get this done as I command you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Performance shall follow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Alack that Leonine was so slack, so slow! He should have struck, not spoke; or that these pirates, Not enough barbarous, had not o'erboard thrown me For to seek my mother!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Why lament you, pretty one?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: That I am pretty.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Come, the gods have done their part in you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: I accuse them not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: You are light into my hands, where you are like to live.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: The more my fault To scape his hands where I was like to die.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Ay, and you shall live in pleasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: No.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Yes, indeed shall you, and taste gentlemen of all fashions: you shall fare well; you shall have the difference of all complexions. What! do you stop your ears?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Are you a woman?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: What would you have me be, an I be not a woman?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: An honest woman, or not a woman.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Marry, whip thee, gosling: I think I shall have something to do with you. Come, you're a young foolish sapling, and must be bowed as I would have you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: The gods defend me!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: If it please the gods to defend you by men, then men must comfort you, men must feed you, men must stir you up. Boult's returned. Now, sir, hast thou cried her through the market?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: I have cried her almost to the number of her hairs; I have drawn her picture with my voice.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: And I prithee tell me, how dost thou find the inclination of the people, especially of the younger sort?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: 'Faith, they listened to me as they would have hearkened to their father's testament. There was a Spaniard's mouth so watered, that he went to bed to her very description.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: We shall have him here to-morrow with his best ruff on.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: To-night, to-night. But, mistress, do you know the French knight that cowers i' the hams?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Who, Monsieur Veroles?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Ay, he: he offered to cut a caper at the proclamation; but he made a groan at it, and swore he would see her to-morrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Well, well; as for him, he brought his disease hither: here he does but repair it. I know he will come in our shadow, to scatter his crowns in the sun.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Well, if we had of every nation a traveller, we should lodge them with this sign.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Pray you, come hither awhile. You have fortunes coming upon you. Mark me: you must seem to do that fearfully which you commit willingly, despise profit where you have most gain. To weep that you live as ye do makes pity in your lovers: seldom but that pity begets you a good opinion, and that opinion a mere profit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: I understand you not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: O, take her home, mistress, take her home: these blushes of hers must be quenched with some present practise.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Thou sayest true, i' faith, so they must; for your bride goes to that with shame which is her way to go with warrant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: 'Faith, some do, and some do not. But, mistress, if I have bargained for the joint,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Thou mayst cut a morsel off the spit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: I may so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Who should deny it? Come, young one, I like the manner of your garments well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Ay, by my faith, they shall not be changed yet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Boult, spend thou that in the town: report what a sojourner we have; you'll lose nothing by custom. When nature flamed this piece, she meant thee a good turn; therefore say what a paragon she is, and thou hast the harvest out of thine own report.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: I warrant you, mistress, thunder shall not so awake the beds of eels as my giving out her beauty stir up the lewdly-inclined. I'll bring home some to-night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: Come your ways; follow me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: If fires be hot, knives sharp, or waters deep, Untied I still my virgin knot will keep. Diana, aid my purpose!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Mytilene. A room in a brothel.
speech.text: What have we to do with Diana? Pray you, will you go with us?

scene.title: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Why, are you foolish? Can it be undone?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: O Dionyza, such a piece of slaughter The sun and moon ne'er look'd upon!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: I think You'll turn a child again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Were I chief lord of all this spacious world, I'ld give it to undo the deed. O lady, Much less in blood than virtue, yet a princess To equal any single crown o' the earth I' the justice of compare! O villain Leonine! Whom thou hast poison'd too: If thou hadst drunk to him, 't had been a kindness Becoming well thy fact: what canst thou say When noble Pericles shall demand his child?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: That she is dead. Nurses are not the fates, To foster it, nor ever to preserve. She died at night; I'll say so. Who can cross it? Unless you play the pious innocent, And for an honest attribute cry out 'She died by foul play.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: O, go to. Well, well, Of all the faults beneath the heavens, the gods Do like this worst.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Be one of those that think The petty wrens of Tarsus will fly hence, And open this to Pericles. I do shame To think of what a noble strain you are, And of how coward a spirit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: To such proceeding Who ever but his approbation added, Though not his prime consent, he did not flow From honourable sources.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Be it so, then: Yet none does know, but you, how she came dead, Nor none can know, Leonine being gone. She did disdain my child, and stood between Her and her fortunes: none would look on her, But cast their gazes on Marina's face; Whilst ours was blurted at and held a malkin Not worth the time of day. It pierced me through; And though you call my course unnatural, You not your child well loving, yet I find It greets me as an enterprise of kindness Perform'd to your sole daughter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Heavens forgive it!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: And as for Pericles, What should he say? We wept after her hearse, And yet we mourn: her monument Is almost finish'd, and her epitaphs In glittering golden characters express A general praise to her, and care in us At whose expense 'tis done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: Thou art like the harpy, Which, to betray, dost, with thine angel's face, Seize with thine eagle's talons.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Tarsus. A room in CLEON's house.
speech.text: You are like one that superstitiously Doth swear to the gods that winter kills the flies: But yet I know you'll do as I advise.

scene.title: SCENE IV

speech.stagedir: Enter GOWER, before the monument of MARINA at Tarsus
speech.sceneN: SCENE IV
speech.text: Thus time we waste, and longest leagues make short; Sail seas in cockles, have an wish but for't; Making, to take your imagination, From bourn to bourn, region to region. By you being pardon'd, we commit no crime To use one language in each several clime Where our scenes seem to live. I do beseech you To learn of me, who stand i' the gaps to teach you, The stages of our story. Pericles Is now again thwarting the wayward seas, Attended on by many a lord and knight. To see his daughter, all his life's delight. Old Escanes, whom Helicanus late Advanced in time to great and high estate, Is left to govern. Bear you it in mind, Old Helicanus goes along behind. Well-sailing ships and bounteous winds have brought This king to Tarsus,--think his pilot thought; So with his steerage shall your thoughts grow on,-- To fetch his daughter home, who first is gone. Like motes and shadows see them move awhile; Your ears unto your eyes I'll reconcile. See how belief may suffer by foul show! This borrow'd passion stands for true old woe; And Pericles, in sorrow all devour'd, With sighs shot through, and biggest tears o'ershower'd, Leaves Tarsus and again embarks. He swears Never to wash his face, nor cut his hairs: He puts on sackcloth, and to sea. He bears A tempest, which his mortal vessel tears, And yet he rides it out. Now please you wit. The epitaph is for Marina writ By wicked Dionyza. 'The fairest, sweet'st, and best lies here, Who wither'd in her spring of year. She was of Tyrus the king's daughter, On whom foul death hath made this slaughter; Marina was she call'd; and at her birth, Thetis, being proud, swallow'd some part o' the earth: Therefore the earth, fearing to be o'erflow'd, Hath Thetis' birth-child on the heavens bestow'd: Wherefore she does, and swears she'll never stint, Make raging battery upon shores of flint.' No visor does become black villany So well as soft and tender flattery. Let Pericles believe his daughter's dead, And bear his courses to be ordered By Lady Fortune; while our scene must play His daughter's woe and heavy well-a-day In her unholy service. Patience, then, And think you now are all in Mytilene.

scene.title: SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from the brothel, two Gentlemen
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.
speech.text: Did you ever hear the like?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from the brothel, two Gentlemen
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.
speech.text: No, nor never shall do in such a place as this, she being once gone.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from the brothel, two Gentlemen
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.
speech.text: But to have divinity preached there! did you ever dream of such a thing?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from the brothel, two Gentlemen
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.
speech.text: No, no. Come, I am for no more bawdy-houses: shall's go hear the vestals sing?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from the brothel, two Gentlemen
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Mytilene. A street before the brothel.
speech.text: I'll do any thing now that is virtuous; but I am out of the road of rutting for ever.

scene.title: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Well, I had rather than twice the worth of her she had ne'er come here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Fie, fie upon her! she's able to freeze the god Priapus, and undo a whole generation. We must either get her ravished, or be rid of her. When she should do for clients her fitment, and do me the kindness of our profession, she has me her quirks, her reasons, her master reasons, her prayers, her knees; that she would make a puritan of the devil, if he should cheapen a kiss of her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: 'Faith, I must ravish her, or she'll disfurnish us of all our cavaliers, and make our swearers priests.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Now, the pox upon her green-sickness for me!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: 'Faith, there's no way to be rid on't but by the way to the pox. Here comes the Lord Lysimachus disguised.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: We should have both lord and lown, if the peevish baggage would but give way to customers.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: How now! How a dozen of virginities?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Now, the gods to-bless your honour!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I am glad to see your honour in good health.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: You may so; 'tis the better for you that your resorters stand upon sound legs. How now! wholesome iniquity have you that a man may deal withal, and defy the surgeon?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: We have here one, sir, if she would--but there never came her like in Mytilene.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: If she'ld do the deed of darkness, thou wouldst say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Your honour knows what 'tis to say well enough.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Well, call forth, call forth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: For flesh and blood, sir, white and red, you shall see a rose; and she were a rose indeed, if she had but--

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: What, prithee?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: O, sir, I can be modest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: That dignifies the renown of a bawd, no less than it gives a good report to a number to be chaste.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Here comes that which grows to the stalk; never plucked yet, I can assure you. Is she not a fair creature?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: 'Faith, she would serve after a long voyage at sea. Well, there's for you: leave us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I beseech your honour, give me leave: a word, and I'll have done presently.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I beseech you, do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: First, I would have you note, this is an honourable man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I desire to find him so, that I may worthily note him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Next, he's the governor of this country, and a man whom I am bound to.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: If he govern the country, you are bound to him indeed; but how honourable he is in that, I know not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Pray you, without any more virginal fencing, will you use him kindly? He will line your apron with gold.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: What he will do graciously, I will thankfully receive.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Ha' you done?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: My lord, she's not paced yet: you must take some pains to work her to your manage. Come, we will leave his honour and her together. Go thy ways.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Now, pretty one, how long have you been at this trade?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: What trade, sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Why, I cannot name't but I shall offend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I cannot be offended with my trade. Please you to name it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: How long have you been of this profession?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: E'er since I can remember.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Did you go to 't so young? Were you a gamester at five or at seven?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Earlier too, sir, if now I be one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Why, the house you dwell in proclaims you to be a creature of sale.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Do you know this house to be a place of such resort, and will come into 't? I hear say you are of honourable parts, and are the governor of this place.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Why, hath your principal made known unto you who I am?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Who is my principal?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Why, your herb-woman; she that sets seeds and roots of shame and iniquity. O, you have heard something of my power, and so stand aloof for more serious wooing. But I protest to thee, pretty one, my authority shall not see thee, or else look friendly upon thee. Come, bring me to some private place: come, come.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: How's this? how's this? Some more; be sage.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: For me, That am a maid, though most ungentle fortune Have placed me in this sty, where, since I came, Diseases have been sold dearer than physic, O, that the gods Would set me free from this unhallow'd place, Though they did change me to the meanest bird That flies i' the purer air!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I did not think Thou couldst have spoke so well; ne'er dream'd thou couldst. Had I brought hither a corrupted mind, Thy speech had alter'd it. Hold, here's gold for thee: Persever in that clear way thou goest, And the gods strengthen thee!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: The good gods preserve you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: For me, be you thoughten That I came with no ill intent; for to me The very doors and windows savour vilely. Fare thee well. Thou art a piece of virtue, and I doubt not but thy training hath been noble. Hold, here's more gold for thee. A curse upon him, die he like a thief, That robs thee of thy goodness! If thou dost Hear from me, it shall be for thy good.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I beseech your honour, one piece for me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Avaunt, thou damned door-keeper! Your house, but for this virgin that doth prop it, Would sink and overwhelm you. Away!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: How's this? We must take another course with you. If your peevish chastity, which is not worth a breakfast in the cheapest country under the cope, shall undo a whole household, let me be gelded like a spaniel. Come your ways.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Whither would you have me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: I must have your maidenhead taken off, or the common hangman shall execute it. Come your ways. We'll have no more gentlemen driven away. Come your ways, I say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: How now! what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Worse and worse, mistress; she has here spoken holy words to the Lord Lysimachus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: O abominable!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: She makes our profession as it were to stink afore the face of the gods.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Marry, hang her up for ever!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: The nobleman would have dealt with her like a nobleman, and she sent him away as cold as a snowball; saying his prayers too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Boult, take her away; use her at thy pleasure: crack the glass of her virginity, and make the rest malleable.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: An if she were a thornier piece of ground than she is, she shall be ploughed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Hark, hark, you gods!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: She conjures: away with her! Would she had never come within my doors! Marry, hang you! She's born to undo us. Will you not go the way of women-kind? Marry, come up, my dish of chastity with rosemary and bays!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Come, mistress; come your ways with me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Whither wilt thou have me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: To take from you the jewel you hold so dear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Prithee, tell me one thing first.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Come now, your one thing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: What canst thou wish thine enemy to be?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Why, I could wish him to be my master, or rather, my mistress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Neither of these are so bad as thou art, Since they do better thee in their command. Thou hold'st a place, for which the pained'st fiend Of hell would not in reputation change: Thou art the damned doorkeeper to every Coistrel that comes inquiring for his Tib; To the choleric fisting of every rogue Thy ear is liable; thy food is such As hath been belch'd on by infected lungs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: What would you have me do? go to the wars, would you? where a man may serve seven years for the loss of a leg, and have not money enough in the end to buy him a wooden one?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Do any thing but this thou doest. Empty Old receptacles, or common shores, of filth; Serve by indenture to the common hangman: Any of these ways are yet better than this; For what thou professest, a baboon, could he speak, Would own a name too dear. O, that the gods Would safely deliver me from this place! Here, here's gold for thee. If that thy master would gain by thee, Proclaim that I can sing, weave, sew, and dance, With other virtues, which I'll keep from boast: And I will undertake all these to teach. I doubt not but this populous city will Yield many scholars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: But can you teach all this you speak of?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Prove that I cannot, take me home again, And prostitute me to the basest groom That doth frequent your house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: Well, I will see what I can do for thee: if I can place thee, I will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: But amongst honest women.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. The same. A room in the brothel.
speech.text: 'Faith, my acquaintance lies little amongst them. But since my master and mistress have bought you, there's no going but by their consent: therefore I will make them acquainted with your purpose, and I doubt not but I shall find them tractable enough. Come, I'll do for thee what I can; come your ways.

scene.title: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.

speech.stagedir: Enter two Sailors, one belonging to the Tyrian vessel, the other to the barge; to them HELICANUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Where is lord Helicanus? he can resolve you. O, here he is. Sir, there's a barge put off from Mytilene, And in it is Lysimachus the governor, Who craves to come aboard. What is your will?

speech.stagedir: Enter two Sailors, one belonging to the Tyrian vessel, the other to the barge; to them HELICANUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: That he have his. Call up some gentlemen.

speech.stagedir: Enter two Sailors, one belonging to the Tyrian vessel, the other to the barge; to them HELICANUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Ho, gentlemen! my lord calls.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Doth your lordship call?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Gentlemen, there's some of worth would come aboard; I pray ye, greet them fairly.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir, This is the man that can, in aught you would, Resolve you.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Hail, reverend sir! the gods preserve you!

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: And you, sir, to outlive the age I am, And die as I would do.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: You wish me well. Being on shore, honouring of Neptune's triumphs, Seeing this goodly vessel ride before us, I made to it, to know of whence you are.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: First, what is your place?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I am the governor of this place you lie before.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir, Our vessel is of Tyre, in it the king; A man who for this three months hath not spoken To any one, nor taken sustenance But to prorogue his grief.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Upon what ground is his distemperature?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: May we not see him?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: You may; But bootless is your sight: he will not speak To any.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Yet let me obtain my wish.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Behold him. This was a goodly person, Till the disaster that, one mortal night, Drove him to this.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir king, all hail! the gods preserve you! Hail, royal sir!

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: It is in vain; he will not speak to you.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir, We have a maid in Mytilene, I durst wager, Would win some words of him.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from thence, LYSIMACHUS and Lords; with the Gentlemen and the two Sailors
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: 'Tis well bethought. She questionless with her sweet harmony And other chosen attractions, would allure, And make a battery through his deafen'd parts, Which now are midway stopp'd: She is all happy as the fairest of all, And, with her fellow maids is now upon The leafy shelter that abuts against The island's side.

speech.stagedir: Whispers a Lord, who goes off in the barge of LYSIMACHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sure, all's effectless; yet nothing we'll omit That bears recovery's name. But, since your kindness We have stretch'd thus far, let us beseech you That for our gold we may provision have, Wherein we are not destitute for want, But weary for the staleness.

speech.stagedir: Whispers a Lord, who goes off in the barge of LYSIMACHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: O, sir, a courtesy Which if we should deny, the most just gods For every graff would send a caterpillar, And so afflict our province. Yet once more Let me entreat to know at large the cause Of your king's sorrow.

speech.stagedir: Whispers a Lord, who goes off in the barge of LYSIMACHUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sit, sir, I will recount it to you: But, see, I am prevented.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter, from the barge, Lord, with MARINA, and a young Lady
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: O, here is The lady that I sent for. Welcome, fair one! Is't not a goodly presence?

speech.stagedir: Re-enter, from the barge, Lord, with MARINA, and a young Lady
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: She's a gallant lady.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter, from the barge, Lord, with MARINA, and a young Lady
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: She's such a one, that, were I well assured Came of a gentle kind and noble stock, I'ld wish no better choice, and think me rarely wed. Fair one, all goodness that consists in bounty Expect even here, where is a kingly patient: If that thy prosperous and artificial feat Can draw him but to answer thee in aught, Thy sacred physic shall receive such pay As thy desires can wish.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter, from the barge, Lord, with MARINA, and a young Lady
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir, I will use My utmost skill in his recovery, Provided That none but I and my companion maid Be suffer'd to come near him.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter, from the barge, Lord, with MARINA, and a young Lady
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Come, let us leave her; And the gods make her prosperous!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Mark'd he your music?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: No, nor look'd on us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: See, she will speak to him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Hail, sir! my lord, lend ear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Hum, ha!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I am a maid, My lord, that ne'er before invited eyes, But have been gazed on like a comet: she speaks, My lord, that, may be, hath endured a grief Might equal yours, if both were justly weigh'd. Though wayward fortune did malign my state, My derivation was from ancestors Who stood equivalent with mighty kings: But time hath rooted out my parentage, And to the world and awkward casualties Bound me in servitude. I will desist; But there is something glows upon my cheek, And whispers in mine ear, 'Go not till he speak.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: My fortunes--parentage--good parentage-- To equal mine!--was it not thus? what say you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I said, my lord, if you did know my parentage, You would not do me violence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I do think so. Pray you, turn your eyes upon me. You are like something that--What country-woman? Here of these shores?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: No, nor of any shores: Yet I was mortally brought forth, and am No other than I appear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Where I am but a stranger: from the deck You may discern the place.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Where were you bred? And how achieved you these endowments, which You make more rich to owe?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: If I should tell my history, it would seem Like lies disdain'd in the reporting.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Prithee, speak: Falseness cannot come from thee; for thou look'st Modest as Justice, and thou seem'st a palace For the crown'd Truth to dwell in: I will believe thee, And make my senses credit thy relation To points that seem impossible; for thou look'st Like one I loved indeed. What were thy friends? Didst thou not say, when I did push thee back-- Which was when I perceived thee--that thou camest From good descending?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: So indeed I did.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Report thy parentage. I think thou said'st Thou hadst been toss'd from wrong to injury, And that thou thought'st thy griefs might equal mine, If both were open'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Some such thing I said, and said no more but what my thoughts Did warrant me was likely.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Tell thy story; If thine consider'd prove the thousandth part Of my endurance, thou art a man, and I Have suffer'd like a girl: yet thou dost look Like Patience gazing on kings' graves, and smiling Extremity out of act. What were thy friends? How lost thou them? Thy name, my most kind virgin? Recount, I do beseech thee: come, sit by me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: My name is Marina.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: O, I am mock'd, And thou by some incensed god sent hither To make the world to laugh at me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Patience, good sir, Or here I'll cease.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Nay, I'll be patient. Thou little know'st how thou dost startle me, To call thyself Marina.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: The name Was given me by one that had some power, My father, and a king.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: How! a king's daughter? And call'd Marina?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: But are you flesh and blood? Have you a working pulse? and are no fairy? Motion! Well; speak on. Where were you born? And wherefore call'd Marina?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Call'd Marina For I was born at sea.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: At sea! what mother?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: My mother was the daughter of a king; Who died the minute I was born, As my good nurse Lychorida hath oft Deliver'd weeping.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: O, stop there a little! This is the rarest dream that e'er dull sleep Did mock sad fools withal: this cannot be: My daughter's buried. Well: where were you bred? I'll hear you more, to the bottom of your story, And never interrupt you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: You scorn: believe me, 'twere best I did give o'er.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I will believe you by the syllable Of what you shall deliver. Yet, give me leave: How came you in these parts? where were you bred?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: The king my father did in Tarsus leave me; Till cruel Cleon, with his wicked wife, Did seek to murder me: and having woo'd A villain to attempt it, who having drawn to do't, A crew of pirates came and rescued me; Brought me to Mytilene. But, good sir, Whither will you have me? Why do you weep? It may be, You think me an impostor: no, good faith; I am the daughter to King Pericles, If good King Pericles be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Ho, Helicanus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Calls my lord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Thou art a grave and noble counsellor, Most wise in general: tell me, if thou canst, What this maid is, or what is like to be, That thus hath made me weep?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I know not; but Here is the regent, sir, of Mytilene Speaks nobly of her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: She would never tell Her parentage; being demanded that, She would sit still and weep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: O Helicanus, strike me, honour'd sir; Give me a gash, put me to present pain; Lest this great sea of joys rushing upon me O'erbear the shores of my mortality, And drown me with their sweetness. O, come hither, Thou that beget'st him that did thee beget; Thou that wast born at sea, buried at Tarsus, And found at sea again! O Helicanus, Down on thy knees, thank the holy gods as loud As thunder threatens us: this is Marina. What was thy mother's name? tell me but that, For truth can never be confirm'd enough, Though doubts did ever sleep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: First, sir, I pray, What is your title?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I am Pericles of Tyre: but tell me now My drown'd queen's name, as in the rest you said Thou hast been godlike perfect, The heir of kingdoms and another like To Pericles thy father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Is it no more to be your daughter than To say my mother's name was Thaisa? Thaisa was my mother, who did end The minute I began.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir, 'tis the governor of Mytilene, Who, hearing of your melancholy state, Did come to see you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: I embrace you. Give me my robes. I am wild in my beholding. O heavens bless my girl! But, hark, what music? Tell Helicanus, my Marina, tell him O'er, point by point, for yet he seems to doubt, How sure you are my daughter. But, what music?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: My lord, I hear none.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: None! The music of the spheres! List, my Marina.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: It is not good to cross him; give him way.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Rarest sounds! Do ye not hear?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: My lord, I hear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Most heavenly music! It nips me unto listening, and thick slumber Hangs upon mine eyes: let me rest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: A pillow for his head: So, leave him all. Well, my companion friends, If this but answer to my just belief, I'll well remember you.

speech.stagedir: DIANA appears to PERICLES as in a vision
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: My temple stands in Ephesus: hie thee thither, And do upon mine altar sacrifice. There, when my maiden priests are met together, Before the people all, Reveal how thou at sea didst lose thy wife: To mourn thy crosses, with thy daughter's, call And give them repetition to the life. Or perform my bidding, or thou livest in woe; Do it, and happy; by my silver bow! Awake, and tell thy dream.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Celestial Dian, goddess argentine, I will obey thee. Helicanus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: My purpose was for Tarsus, there to strike The inhospitable Cleon; but I am For other service first: toward Ephesus Turn our blown sails; eftsoons I'll tell thee why. Shall we refresh us, sir, upon your shore, And give you gold for such provision As our intents will need?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir, With all my heart; and, when you come ashore, I have another suit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: You shall prevail, Were it to woo my daughter; for it seems You have been noble towards her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Sir, lend me your arm.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. On board PERICLES' ship, off Mytilene. A close pavilion on deck, with a curtain before it; PERICLES within it, reclined on a couch. A barge lying beside the Tyrian vessel.
speech.text: Come, my Marina.

scene.title: SCENE II

speech.stagedir: Enter GOWER, before the temple of DIANA at Ephesus
speech.sceneN: SCENE II
speech.text: Now our sands are almost run; More a little, and then dumb. This, my last boon, give me, For such kindness must relieve me, That you aptly will suppose What pageantry, what feats, what shows, What minstrelsy, and pretty din, The regent made in Mytilene To greet the king. So he thrived, That he is promised to be wived To fair Marina; but in no wise Till he had done his sacrifice, As Dian bade: whereto being bound, The interim, pray you, all confound. In feather'd briefness sails are fill'd, And wishes fall out as they're will'd. At Ephesus, the temple see, Our king and all his company. That he can hither come so soon, Is by your fancy's thankful doom.

scene.title: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, with his train; LYSIMACHUS, HELICANUS, MARINA, and a Lady
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Hail, Dian! to perform thy just command, I here confess myself the king of Tyre; Who, frighted from my country, did wed At Pentapolis the fair Thaisa. At sea in childbed died she, but brought forth A maid-child call'd Marina; who, O goddess, Wears yet thy silver livery. She at Tarsus Was nursed with Cleon; who at fourteen years He sought to murder: but her better stars Brought her to Mytilene; 'gainst whose shore Riding, her fortunes brought the maid aboard us, Where, by her own most clear remembrance, she Made known herself my daughter.

speech.stagedir: Enter PERICLES, with his train; LYSIMACHUS, HELICANUS, MARINA, and a Lady
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Voice and favour! You are, you are--O royal Pericles!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: What means the nun? she dies! help, gentlemen!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Noble sir, If you have told Diana's altar true, This is your wife.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Reverend appearer, no; I threw her overboard with these very arms.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Upon this coast, I warrant you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: 'Tis most certain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Look to the lady; O, she's but o'erjoy'd. Early in blustering morn this lady was Thrown upon this shore. I oped the coffin, Found there rich jewels; recover'd her, and placed her Here in Diana's temple.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: May we see them?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Great sir, they shall be brought you to my house, Whither I invite you. Look, Thaisa is recovered.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: O, let me look! If he be none of mine, my sanctity Will to my sense bend no licentious ear, But curb it, spite of seeing. O, my lord, Are you not Pericles? Like him you spake, Like him you are: did you not name a tempest, A birth, and death?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: The voice of dead Thaisa!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: That Thaisa am I, supposed dead And drown'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Immortal Dian!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Now I know you better. When we with tears parted Pentapolis, The king my father gave you such a ring.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: This, this: no more, you gods! your present kindness Makes my past miseries sports: you shall do well, That on the touching of her lips I may Melt and no more be seen. O, come, be buried A second time within these arms.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: My heart Leaps to be gone into my mother's bosom.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
SCENE III. The temple of Diana at Ephesus; THAISA standing near the altar, as high priestess; a number of Virgins on each side; CERIMON and other Inhabitants of Ephesus attending.
speech.text: Blest, and mine own!
